--- Page 5 ---
UT.A 
diamond's 
beauty 
and 
value
also depend o n the w a y i t refracts light for
brilliance, ﬁre  a n d sparkle. Most  diamonds
are cut t o have 5 8 facets, transforming them
into 
a prism 
that 
breaks 
u p 
light 
into 
a l l 
colors
of 
the 
spectrum.
I f 
the 
facets 
are 
not 
positioned 
a t 
precise
angles, light will escape through the  bottom
o r sides o f the diamond, making it  less bril-
liant. 
A perfectly 
cut 
diamond 
will  
reﬂect 
all
the light upwards for maximum brilliance.
K e e p y o u r diamonds  sparkling
T h e s p a r k l e o f a d i a m o n d is  a l w a y s t h e r e . C l e a n dia-monds  "glow" because the  maximum amount o f light
can enter and return in a ﬁery brilliance. Diamonds
have an afﬁnity for grease. Skin oils, soap, powder and
cooking 
grease 
can 
put 
a 
ﬁlm  
o n 
diamonds 
and 
cut
d o w n their brilliance. K e e p them  clean a n d y o u keep
them 
beautiful.
Popular diamond shapes
Brilliant-the  round diamond that is a favor-
ite i n engagement rings.I n tiny sizes, and
with only 1 6 facets, this shape is  called a
single cut and is  used as a side stone in rings.
Facts  about  diamonds
Cmerald cut - s o called because emeralds are
often cut this way, rectangular o r square, with
facets polished diagonally across the corners.
Marquise 
—a  pointed 
boat 
shape, 
usually 
long
a n d narrow.
I n 
a 
ring, 
it  
tends 
to 
make 
the
ﬁngers look slim.
Pear shape-popular i n rings and often used
in 
pendants. 
The 
world's 
largest 
cut 
diamond,
Cullinan 
I , 
mounted 
i n 
the 
British 
Royal 
Scep-
tre, is  a pear shape.
Oval-an 
adaptation 
of 
the 
brilliant 
shape.
The marquise, pear shape and oval all appear
to be larger than a brilliant of the same carat
weight.
The  "144", THE  WORLD'S
MOST EXCITING DIAMONDS
An Ordinary 58 Cut Diamond The 144 Cut Diamond
Some 3 2 % more scintillation on the average. This
ﬁrst signiﬁcant improvement in 60 years adds
brilliance and beauty to the diamond you choose
from 
Ben 
Bridge, 
the 
exclusive 
distributor 
o f 
this
cut i n this area. Available i n all sizes of diamonds.
See and compare today. Patent # U S . 3-286-486.
-
Ben 
BridgeJeweler since  1912

OLOR.The 
most 
desirable 
diamonds
are "white," o r colorless. Diamonds that are
absolutely without color are very rare and are
valued 
accordingly. 
Those 
with 
a noticeable
yellowish 
hue 
are 
the 
least 
desirable. 
Even 
a
slight tinge o f yellow can seriously reduce
a diamond's value. A colorless d i a m o n d is
worth 
considerably 
more 
- 
even 
i f 
it  
con-
tains 
slight 
imperfections 
— 
than 
a diamond
of 
average 
color.
ARAT  WEIGHT . This i s the unit of
weight 
used 
f o r 
diamonds. 
There 
are 
100
points t o a carat. Approximately half the
weight o f a "rough" o r uncut diamond will
be  lost i n cutting. The  larger the diamond, the
rarer it  i s . A single large diamond has  con-
siderably greater value than two o r more dia-
monds 
comparable 
i n 
quality 
and 
totaling 
the
same weight as  the single stone.
Although 
you 
may 
expect 
a 
"half 
carat"
d i a m o n d to
w e i g h 
5 0 
points, 
i t 
may
actually weigh from 4 3 t o 5 7 points a n d stilli
be called a "half carat."
Our Master Diamonds
are GIA graded, scien-
tiﬁcally calibrated in
the
Diamondlite 
with
classiﬁcationsun-
derstandable 
by 
any
professional.
Each diamond is  weighed
to the  closest  1 / 2 0 0 o f a
c a r a t , a n d e a c h mounted
set  is m a r k e d w i t h the  ex-
act 
weight 
o f 
every 
dia-
m o n d in it  t o assure  your
getting full value.
G.I.A. Diamondlite
Mettler Electronic

Stones i n these grades will  "face  up" colorless
(i.e. slight traces o f color will not be apparent in
mounted 
stones 
t o 
other 
than 
the 
trained 
eye.)
Small 
stones 
in 
this 
range
will"face  up"colorless
when mounted but larger
stones will be tinted.
Mounted stones these grades will display a
yellowish tint even t o the untrained eye.
COLOR + CARAT WEIGHT + CLARITY + CUT  = $ VA L U E
～ カ ラ
08
& LARITY . A ﬂawless diamond is
extremely rare. Most diamonds contain natu-
ral  
imperfections 
o r 
"inclusions" 
— 
tiny 
crys-
tals  
o f 
carbon 
o r 
bubbles 
o f 
gas  
included 
in
the 
stone 
when 
i t 
was 
crystallized 
from 
car-
bon 
millions 
o f 
years 
ago.
W h e n a gemologist grades a diamond for
clarity , 
he  
must  
consider 
the  
location 
o f 
any
inclusion i n the g e m . I f it  does n o t interfere
with 
the 
refraction 
o f 
light, 
the 
diamond's
beauty is  not affected.

grade  c o l o r s . As  the least expensive
diamonds  in the  near-colorless  range,J-color diamonds  present  the best
value in d i a m o n d color, so you canbuy a l a r g e r diamond for the price.

eye.
